title: 113_hr5790
content: The Act titled "Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014" introduces prize competitions for improving health outcomes and reducing federal expenditures under the Public Health Service Act. The Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014 aims to improve health outcomes and reduce Federal expenditures on health programs through prize competitions. Within 6 months of enactment, the Director of NIH will identify 3 to 5 diseases or health conditions with significant Federal spending on prevention and treatment activities but limited research investment compared to other similar diseases. The Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014 aims to address the disproportionate investment in research for certain diseases compared to their prevention and treatment expenditures. The Director of NIH will design prize competitions to encourage innovation in achieving health goals for identified diseases. The Director of NIH will design prize competitions to cooperate with competitors and award prizes for innovative solutions to achieve health goals for identified diseases. The competitions will be realistic based on the funds available for prizes. The Director of NIH will design prize competitions to award prizes for innovative solutions to achieve health goals for identified diseases. The competitions will be realistic based on the funds available for prizes and will not show bias towards any particular type of innovation. Any person can participate as a competitor regardless of their place of incorporation, primary place of business, citizenship, and residency. The competitions will address areas of unmet need with regard to a lack of recent and pending innovations. A report on the design of such competitions will be submitted to Congress. The Director of NIH will consult with experts and relevant federal agencies to design prize competitions for innovative health solutions. A simulation of the competitions will be conducted within 14 months of the enactment of the Health Prizes Rewarding Innovation, Savings, and Effectiveness Act of 2014. The Director of NIH will award contracts for a simulation of prize competitions within 14 months of the Act's enactment. A report on the simulation results must be submitted to Congress within 4 months of awarding the contracts. Adjustments to the competition design will be made within 21 months based on the simulation results. The Director of NIH will adjust the design of prize competitions based on simulation results within 21 months of the Act's enactment. Private entities will implement the competitions, requiring demonstration of innovation effectiveness over a maximum of 5 years. The Director of NIH will conduct a total of 5 prize competitions, with a maximum of 2 competitions per disease or condition. Competitors must demonstrate innovation effectiveness over a period of up to 5 years, with guidance and access to testing facilities provided by the Secretary and the Commissioner of Food and Drugs. The Director will track and report on the medical efficacy of innovations funded through the competitions. The Director of NIH will conduct up to 5 prize competitions, limited to 2 per disease or condition. They will track the medical efficacy of funded innovations and report to Congress annually for 5 years. The government cannot acquire intellectual property without participant consent. The Federal Government cannot acquire intellectual property rights without participant consent in prize competitions. The government may negotiate licenses for the use of intellectual property. $50,000,000 is authorized for appropriations to carry out this section, with a maximum of 30% of assistance for administration of prize competitions. Under subsection (e), assistance awarded to private entities for prize competitions must allocate not more than 30% for administration and at least 70% as prizes to competitors. Section 74 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to exclude the value of prizes received from prize competitions under section 409K of the Public Health Service Act from gross income. This amendment applies to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act.
